questions.text: The disaccharide shown below is present abundantly in which of the following food?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Milk As the bond is β(1→4) bond, we can easily identify this molecule as lactose . Because only lactose has beta-bond. Other common disaccharides usually have α-bonds (see other figures) Lactose is the major sugar in milk .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Spinach Spinach mostly contains some complex carbohydrates and a minor amount of sugar. Free galactose is not present in the spinach It is a good source of B vitamins and important minerals Option C: Table Sugar Table sugar contains sucrose which is a disaccharide made of glucose and fructose joined by α (1→2) bond . Due to no free functional group, it is non-reducing in nature. Also, present abundantly in sugarcane juice and sugar beet. Option D: Germinating grain In the germinating grains, maltose/malt sugar is formed by the action of α-amylases which hydrolyses stored starch to maltose, and limit dextrins, and other smaller oligosaccharides by breaking α(1→4) glycosidic bonds. Maltose is also present in fruits, honey, and corn syrup

questions.text: The type of transport mechanism across the membrane shown in the picture is known as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ping pong This is the Ping Pong mechanism of transport shown. In the PING state, the carrier is loaded . Then conformational change occurs. In the PONG state, the carrier is unloaded towards the other side of the membrane. This occurs in the case of facilitative transport for glucose i.e. GLUTs .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Symport Movement of two different molecules simultaneously in the same direction For example: sodium-glucose symporter in the intestine Option C: Uniport Movement of one molecule at a time (unidirectional) by transporter, For example: the transport of fructose and glucose in the intestine by GLUTs The rate at which glucose (solute) enters a cell via GLUT depends upon: Number of GLUTs (most important) Concentration of glucose The affinity of GLUT for glucose. Note: Though the above picture also depicts a uniport, the more accurate answer would be the ping-pong mechanism. Option D: Antiport Movement of two different molecules simultaneously in the opposite direction. For example: chloride-bicarbonate transport in the red blood cell (RBC).

questions.text: A section of intestinal brush border membrane is shown in the picture. Identify the glucose transporters present at marked points X and Y:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

X-SGLT-1, Y-GLUT-2 In the intestine, both facilitative transport (GLUT) and secondary active (SGLT) transport are present. At the apical membrane, on the Luminal side of intestinal cells, SGLT-1 (Sodium dependent Glucose Transporter-1) is present. It transports glucose and galactose in a Na + coupled symport. At the basolateral membrane towards the interstitial fluid side, facilitative transporter GLUT-2 is present that transport glucose from the intestinal cell into blood using facilitated diffusion . In kidneys also (see fig below), both facilitative transport (GLUT) and secondary active (SGLT) transport are present.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A and D: X-SGLT-2, Y-GLUT-2 and X-GLUT-2, Y-SGLT-2 SGLT-2 is present only in the kidneys for the reabsorption of glucose. Option B: X-GLUT-3, Y-SGLT-1 GLUT-3 is present in Brain (Neuronal), Placenta, and Kidneys for basal glucose uptake

questions.text: The type of isomerism between two isomers of glucose shown in the image below is known as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Enantiomerism Isomerism in which there is different H & OH orientations around the Penultimate/Reference/2 nd last carbon Isomers are also known as mirror images of each other e.g. D-and L-Glyceraldehyde and D-glucose and L-glucose. If at penultimate carbon -OH is on right it is given the designation as D isomer and if -OH is on left it is given the designation as L isomer (See fig below). Note: As seen in glucose, the orientation of -H and -OH changes at all of the chiral carbons but for giving D- and L- notations, we look at the penultimate carbon / 2nd last carbon. That’s why it is also known as reference carbon. The sugars abundantly present in human is D-form whereas L-amino acid are abundantly present in the proteins.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Anomersism Isomerism in which there is different H and OH orientation around asymmetric functional carbon e.g. α-glucose and β-glucose It is present in the cyclic form of sugars. Two types of anomers are: Alpha (α) - at functional carbon, –OH is downwards Beta (β) - at functional carbon, –OH is upwards Option C: Epimerism Epimers are stereoisomers that differ in configuration around a single asymmetric carbon other than the anomeric carbon. Epimers of glucose can be remembered as M annose -C2 epimer, A llose -C3 epimer, G alactose -C4 epimer I dose -C5 epimer. Option D: Diastereomers Diastereomers are those stereoisomers that differ in H and OH configuration around one or more stereocenters but not all of them. Epimers are also diastereomers with different configurations around only one stereocenter. They differ from enantiomers in that the enantiomers have different conformation around all the stereocenters. Examples are Mannose and galactose which differ in configuration at two chiral centers

options.label: D
options.text: D-Enantiomer of glucose at C-2 and C-3

questions.correct_answer: C. Epimer of glucose at C-2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epimer of glucose at C-2 This structure shown is Mannose . Epimerism is different H and OH orientation at one chiral center. Mannose is an epimer of glucose at C-2.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Epimer of glucose at C-4 Mannose has the same configuration as glucose at C-4. So, it cannot be epimer at C-4. Galactose is an epimer of glucose at C-4. Options B and D: Enantiomer of glucose at C-4 D-Enantiomer of glucose at C-2 and C-3 Mannose cannot be an enantiomer of glucose as it has the same configuration as glucose at C3, C4, and C5. Enantiomers are mirror images means that they have different configurations at all the chiral centers . Option D: Enantiomer of glucose at C-2 and C-3 For enantiomer, we compare penultimate carbon for D and L notation. The penultimate carbon in this case is C5. So, option D is false.

Solution:

Optical isomerism In the picture, it can be observed that a plane-polarized light is passed through the solution. After passing through the solution, the light gets rotated. This phenomenon is Optical isomerism. If the light is rotated towards the right side , then the sugar present in the solution is known as dextrorotatory (d) or (+). If the light is rotated towards the left side , then the sugar present in the solution is known as levorotatory (l) or (-). These dextro and levo are optical isomers.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A and D: Enantiomerism Isomerism in which there is different H & OH orientations around the Penultimate/Reference/2 nd last carbon Isomers are also known as mirror images of each other e.g. D-and L-Glyceraldehyde and D-glucose and L-glucose. If at penultimate carbon -OH is on right it is given the designation as D isomer and if -OH is on left it is given the designation as L isomer. Option C: Epimerism Epimers are stereoisomers that differ in configuration around a single asymmetric carbon other than the anomeric carbon. Epimers of glucose can be remembered as M annose -C2 epimer, A llose -C3 epimer, G alactose -C4 epimer I dose -C5 epimer.

questions.text: Identify the kind of channel. This channel is associated with which of the following transporter:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SGLT-1 The s odium potassium ATPase pump is shown in the picture. It is associated with SGLT i.e. sodium-dependent glucose transport. SGLT transport is also known as secondary active transport as the energy is not directly used for sugar transport but rather is used indirectly when sodium ions are pumped out of the cell using a Na + -K + pump and in the process consuming ATP.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and C: GLUT-1, GLUT-4, GLUT-7 GLUTs are facilitative transporters and are not sodium-dependent GLUT-1 is present in Brain, Placenta, Kidney, and RBC and helps in basal glucose uptake GLUT-4 is insulin-dependent and helps in sugar absorption in Skeletal muscles, Cardiac muscles, and Adipose tissues GLUT-7 has a high affinity for both glucose and fructose and is located in cells of the small intestine, colon, testis, and prostate.

questions.text: The bottle shown in the figure contains:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D (+) glucose Option A: D (+) glucose This is a bottle used for IV injection of Dextrose An abundant form of carbohydrate in our body is always the D form 'D’ means structural isomer i.e. Enantiomer with OH on the right side at C5 carbon in glucose (+) or (d) means dextrorotatory. Glucose is always dextrorotatory (d) (+). The solution of glucose is known as Dextrose. Therefore, Dextrose is D (+) glucose

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: D (–) glucose Glucose is always dextrorotatory so D (–) form is not found naturally in humans. Options C and D: L-Glucose does not occur naturally in living organisms but can be synthesized in the laboratory and is indistinguishable in taste from D-glucose. It cannot be used by living organisms as a source of energy because it cannot be phosphorylated by hexokinase the first enzyme of glycolysis.

questions.text: Powder Puff or Hedge Hog appearing osazones in the given figure belong to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lactose Option B: Lactose Osazones All reducing sugars will form osazones with an excess of phenylhydrazine when kept at boiling temperature. Osazones are insoluble and each sugar will have a characteristic crystal form of osazones. Powder Puff or hedgehog-appearing osazones are from lactose.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Glucose Glucose, fructose, and mannose differ in configuration around 1 st and 2 nd C atoms when the osazone is formed, these differences are obliterated. Hence these 3 sugars form the same needle - shaped crystals arranged like sheaves of corn or a broom Options C and D: maltose and galactose Maltose form Sunflower shaped crystal Rhombic shape crystal is formed for Galactose

questions.text: Given is the structure of glycogen. What is the linkage at points ‘a’, ‘b’, and ‘c’ respectively:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

α1→4, α1→6 and α1→4 Option C: α1→4, α1→6 and α1→4 In the structure of glycogen, linear chains have α (1→4) bonds . Only the branching point has α(1→6) bond Point ‘a’ and ‘c’ lies in a linear Point ‘b’ lies at the branch point.
